abstract.p: It is known that in many neurological disorders such as Down syndrome, main brain rhythms shift their frequencies slightly, and characterizing the spatial distribution of these shifts is of interest. This article reports on the development of a Skew-t mixed model for the spatial analysis of resting state brain activity in healthy controls and individuals with Down syndrome. Time series of oscillatory brain activity are recorded using magnetoencephalography, and spectral summaries are examined at multiple sensor locations across the scalp. We focus on the mean frequency of the power spectral density, and use space-varying regression to examine associations with age, gender and Down syndrome across several scalp regions. Spatial smoothing priors are incorporated based on a multivariate Markov random field, and the markedly non-Gaussian nature of the spectral response variable is accommodated by the use of a Skew-t distribution. A range of models representing different assumptions on the association structure and response distribution are examined, and we conduct model selection using the deviance information criterion.1 Our analysis suggests region-specific differences between healthy controls and individuals with Down syndrome, particularly in the left and right temporal regions, and produces smoothed maps indicating the scalp topography of the estimated differences.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Many neurological disorders are associated with a shift in the frequencies of the main brain rhythms. Characterizing the spatial distribution of these shifts is crucial to understanding how a particular disorder will manifest in different regions of the brain. To this end, observational studies of neurodevelopmental disorders often collect imaging data on the brain activity of individuals with disorders, for comparison with a control group. Here, interest lies in population level inference, in uncovering differences between groups, and detecting associations that may vary spatially across a set of brain regions.

In this article, we present a novel statistical approach for the spectral analysis of resting state brain activity collected in magnetoencephalography (MEG)-based group studies. We develop a regression model for non-Gaussian spectral response data, with spatially varying regression coefficients based on a Markov random field. Our proposed methodology is motivated by a study of Down syndrome (DS) involving 46 subjects (19 DS and 27 controls), where spontaneous electromagnetic activity was recorded using an MEG system (151-channel whole cortex system, CTF Systems, Inc., Canada) with sensors located at various locations across the scalp as depicted in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Grouping of 150 MEG sensors into 30 scalp regions. MEG: magnetoencephalography.

For each subject in the study, a time series measuring the magnetic field associated with neural activity is collected at each of 150 MEG sensors while the subject remains in resting state for approximately 5 min, with a sampling rate of 600 Hz. Our analysis proceeds in the frequency domain, and the frequency content of the data is summarized by computing the power spectral density of the time series measured at each scalp location. This density is then summarized through the mean frequency, resulting in a set of 150 spatially referenced response variables summarizing the spectral signature across the scalp of each subject. The subjects in each of the DS and control groups vary in terms of both age and gender, and information on these factors is available.

Understanding the resting state brain activity of individuals with DS is of general interest; moreover, as a clinical population, individuals with DS have an established high risk of developing Alzheimer's disease.2 Postmortem studies show that by the age of 40, almost all individuals with DS have neuropathological changes that meet the pathological criteria for Alzheimer's disease.3 For this reason, researchers are beginning to use DS as a model, to better understand the nature and course of Alzheimer's disease (AD). The earliest neuropathological changes are thought to occur in the medial temporal lobe followed by neocortical association regions. Changes in the frequency content of brain activity in these areas may indicate the beginnings of AD-like pathology in the brains of individuals with DS. The primary objective of the analysis developed here is thus is to conduct inference on the differences between the DS and control populations, and to investigate how these differences vary across different regions of the scalp.

With MEG resting state data, associations between the spectral features of brain activity and various subject-specific factors can be examined through a mixed model analysis.4 Using this approach, an exploratory analysis of the data in our motivating study reveals that a standard mixed model based on a Gaussian response distribution leads to a poor fit, with the corresponding residuals exhibiting skewness and considerable excess kurtosis. As a result, robust models accommodating these features are needed, in order to conduct reliable statistical inference. Transformations to normality are possible in certain situations; however, this approach has been effectively criticized, in particular for correlated data.5 Direct parametric modeling of the skewness and kurtosis through generalizations of the normal distribution is preferable, as this improves the interpretability of the regression model inference.

Flexible parametric modeling with skew-elliptical distributions has received considerable attention in the recent literature.6 A general formulation for multivariate skew-elliptical densities has been described by Azzalini and Capitanio,7 who develop maximum likelihood inference for the special case of regression models based on the multivariate Skew-t distribution. Regression modeling with the univariate Skew-t distribution has also been considered by Fernández and Steel,8 under a slightly different formulation, with inference conducted in a Bayesian framework. For longitudinal data, linear mixed models based on skew-elliptical distributions have recently been proposed by Jara et al.9 who introduce skew-elliptical distributions for modeling both random and error effects, as well as by Ma et al.10 where a generalized skew-elliptical distribution is incorporated for modeling random effects at the second stage of a linear mixed model. In the context of spatially correlated data, a method for kriging with non-Gaussian data was developed by Kim and Mallick,11 who proposed a formulation for a skew-normal spatial process. More recently, Zhang and El-Shaarawi12 used a constructive approach to develop methods for spatial interpolation based on processes having skewed marginal distributions. Focussing on heavy-tails rather than asymmetric distributions, Palacios and Steel13 develop methodology for non-Gaussian geostatistical modeling based on scale mixing of a stationary Gaussian process.

With MEG data collected at various locations across the scalp, it is also important to examine how the associations of interest may vary spatially across different brain regions. In this case, a regression model with coefficients that vary across regions is required, and a formal comparison of such a model to a simpler model with constant coefficients, leading to global associations, is of interest. Bayesian spatially varying coefficient models have been considered by several authors14,15 typically under the assumption of Gaussian distributed regression errors.

With data exhibiting non-Gaussian features, and with the need to assess spatially varying associations in a statistically efficient manner, the resulting analysis is not straightforward, and necessitates the development of new statistical methodology. The primary contribution of this article is the development of a Skew-t spatial regression model, accommodating deviations from a standard Gaussian assumption, and allowing for spatially varying coefficients based on a Markov random field prior. To fit the model in a Bayesian framework, we develop an MCMC algorithm based on a missing data framework that makes use of the stochastic representation underlying skew-elliptical distributions. While motivated by the aforementioned MEG study, the proposed methodology is general, and broadly applicable to the analysis of small area data, when residuals exhibit skewness with heavy-tail behavior, and the estimation of spatially varying associations is of interest.

The remainder of this article is structured as follows. Section 2 describes the spatial layout underlying the resting state MEG data, and the spectral response examined in the subsequent analysis. In Section 3 we review the univariate skew-normal and Skew-t distributions. We discuss some properties of the Skew-t distribution which make it well suited for modeling the spectral response, as well as its representation as a location-scale Gaussian mixture, which we subsequently exploit to fit the model using standard software. In Section 4, a formal space-varying regression model is proposed, and the implementation of Bayesian inference based on a missing data formulation is discussed. Section 5 presents an analysis of spectral slowing in Down syndrome. Beginning with an exploratory analysis, we demonstrate the strong need for non-Gaussian distributions and spatial modeling. Our methodology is then applied to the data, and the results obtained from fitting several hierarchical models are presented and compared. Section 6 concludes with a brief summary.

sec.title: 2 Resting state brain activity and mean frequency
sec.p: Studying resting state brain activity is appealing as the resulting experimental paradigm is relatively simple, and the study may be performed with very low-functioning subjects. Conversely, the statistical analysis of resting state data can be more challenging than the analysis of more traditional event-related measurements, where a stimulus is repeatedly presented, resulting in a strong localized signal. With data collected in resting state, such a signal does not emerge, and this can make standard analysis procedures, that invert the scalp level MEG data to the corresponding source locations within the brain, difficult to apply.

To avoid these difficulties, our analysis proceeds, not at the level of neural sources, but at the level of MEG sensors, with each of 150 sensors collecting a time series of resting state activity, and with sensor locations distributed across the scalp. For each study participant, the head position relative to the sensor array may be slightly different, and as a result, comparisons made at specific sensor locations may be less meaningful than broader comparisons made over a set of larger regions partitioning the scalp. In the present study, adjacent sensors are grouped into 30 larger patches, with each patch containing 4 to 6 sensors, and the combined patch signals reflecting activity in roughly the same area of the brain for all subjects. The grouping of sensors into patches is depicted in Figure 1. In this framework, each sensor contributes to a broader spatial signal at the patch level, and statistical models are formulated to uncover spatial variability at this level.

In our spatial analysis, the time series observed at each sensor is summarized with the mean frequency of the power spectral density, a univariate response. More specifically, if Bt, t = 0, … , T − 1 is the time series of magnetic field measurements at a given MEG sensor, with sampling rate SR, the discrete Fourier transform at frequency ωk is computed as X(ωk)= ∑t=0 T-1Bt×w(t)e-iωkt,k=0,…,T-1, where w(·) is an appropriately defined window function. The spectral density is then S(ωk)=P/(ωk)TSR, where P(ωk) = re(X(ωk))2 + im(X(ωk))2 is the power at ωk. The spectral density is normalized to yield Sn(ωk)=S/(ωk)∑0 T-1S(ωk)/T and from the normalized spectral density, the mean frequency is computed as U=1/2∑LFB HFBSn(ωk), where HFB and LFB are, respectively, pre-chosen values for the high frequency and low frequency bounds. The mean frequency is illustrated graphically in Figure 2. In subsequent analyses, we will work on the log-scale, defining the response at each MEG sensor as Y = log{U}, which makes the homoscedastic assumption underlying the proposed models more tenable. Despite the logarithmic transformation, a regression model based on Gaussian errors results in a poor fit to the mean frequency data. We add the required flexibility by incorporating the Skew-t distribution. Figure 2.
The mean frequencies associated with three signals. Each signal is based on a linear combination of periodic functions.

sec.title: 3 The skew-normal and Skew-t distributions
sec.p:
In this section we briefly introduce the skew-normal and Skew-t distributions, both distributions falling within the broad class of skew-elliptical distributions.6,7 A univariate random variable Y is said to have a skew-normal distribution Y ∼ SN(μ, σ2, α) with location μ ∈ R, scale σ > 0 and shape α ∈ R if it is continuous, with density function (1)PY(y|μ,σ,α)=2/σφ (y/-μσ )Φ (α/(y-μ)σ ),y∈R where φ(·) and Φ(·) denote, respectively, the density and distribution function of the standard normal distribution. The shape parameter α governs the asymmetry of the distribution, with positive and negative values corresponding to positive and negative skewness respectively, and with α = 0 corresponding to the N(μ, σ2) distribution. Generalizing further, the standard construction of the t-distribution through the ratio of a normal random variable and the square-root of an independent χ2 random variable divided by its degrees-of-freedom, can be extended to define a Skew-t distribution via Y=μ+X/W/ν where X ∼ SN(0, σ2, α) and W is independently distributed as χν 2, ν > 0. The resulting four parameter distribution, denoted as St(μ, σ2, α, ν), contains the normal (α = 0, ν → ∞), skew-normal (ν → ∞) and t-distribution (α = 0) as special cases, and has probability density given by (2)PY(y|μ,σ,α,ν)=2t(y;μ,σ,ν)T {α/(y-μ)σ (ν/+1(y-μ)2σ2+ν )1/2;ν+1 } where t(y;μ,σ,ν)=Γ/({ν+1)/2}σ(πν)1/2Γ(ν/2) [1+(y-μ)2νσ2 ]-(ν+1)/2, the density of a t-distribution having location μ, scale σ and ν degrees of freedom; and T(·; ν + 1) is the cumulative distribution function of a standard t-distribution on ν + 1 degrees of freedom. The moments of the Skew-t distribution (2) were derived by Azzalini and Capitanio,5 and in particular, the mean and variance, when these exist (depending on the value of ν), are given by E[Y]=μ+σ/α1+α2(ν/π )1/2Γ/{1/2(ν-1)}Γ(1/2ν),ν>1
Var[Y]=σ2 (ν/ν-2-α21+α2ν/πΓ2{1/2(ν-1)}Γ2(1/2ν) ),ν>2.<label>(3)</label> Finally, we note that the Skew-t distribution can be derived as a Gaussian location-scale mixture.6 More specifically, if Y ∼ St(0, σ, α, ν) then the probability density of Y can be expressed as (4)pY(y)=∫0 ∞∫0 ∞W(1+α2)σφ (y/-(ασZ)/1+α2σ/W(1+α2) )×2Wφ(WZ)×gν(W)dZdW where gν(·) denotes the probability density of a Gamma(ν/2, ν/2) distribution. We shall make use of this mixture representation for fitting models within a latent variable framework.

The Skew-t distribution provides a flexible and intuitive departure from the normal distribution, allowing both asymmetry and heavy tails. We have found it necessary to accommodate these features in developing space-varying regression models for application to the mean frequency response in our motivating application.

sec.title: 4.1 Model specification
sec.p: Given the spatial layout and computations described in Section 2, we let Yijk denote the mean frequency of the power spectral density obtained at the kth MEG sensor, within the jth patch, and on the scalp of subject i. To examine differences between the DS and control groups, while adjusting for age and gender, a mixed model assuming constant associations takes the form (5)Yijk=μ+β1AGEi+β2GENDERi+β3DSi+bi+aij+εijk i=1,…,46;j=1,…,30;k=1,…,mj where mj is the number of sensors in the jth patch; AGEi denotes the age of subject i in years; GENDERi is binary and takes value GENDERi = 1 if subject i is female; DSi is binary with DSi = 1 for subjects with Down syndrome; bi|σb 2iid~N(0,σb 2) and aij|σa 2iid~N(0,σa 2) are random effects accommodating the clustering arising from a nested data structure, with patches within subjects, and sensors within patches; and εijk are the measurement errors. A robust model with added flexibility is based on a Skew-t distribution for the measurement errors εijk|σε,α,νiid~St(0,σε 2,α,ν).

In the regression model (5) the (age and gender adjusted) difference between the DS and control populations is characterized by the regression coefficient β3. This regression model is global in the sense that differences are assumed constant across the regions depicted in Figure 1. A more flexible approach allows the group differences to vary across scalp regions through a space-varying regression model (6)Yijk=μ+βj1AGEi+βj2GENDERi+βj3DSi+bi+aij+εijk where βj=(βj1,βj2,βj3)',j=1,…,30 are the region-specific regression coefficients. We expect a similarity in the coefficients of neighboring regions, which suggests a spatial smoothing prior for β=(β1',…,β30')'. Here, we adopt a multivariate conditional autoregressive prior, which is a Markov random field prior where the joint distribution for β is specified through a set of local (full conditional) distributions.16

We let C denote the binary matrix coding the patch adjacencies depicted in the map of Figure 1, with Cjj = 0, j = 1, … , 30, and assume βj|β-j,Σ~MVN3 (μj,1/Cj+Σ ),j=1,…,30, where β−j denotes the vector β with βj removed; μj is defined as a weighted average μj=∑l=1 30CjlCj+βl; and Σ is a hyperparameter representing the (conditional) covariance of each βj. These conditional specifications are compatible, and lead to a joint distribution for β obtained as p(β|Σ ∝ exp{−1/2β′[(DC − C) ⊗ Σ−1]β}. (see e.g. Carlin and Banerjee17) where DC = diag{C1+, … , C30+}.

The spatial smoothing prior adopted here is based on the prior knowledge that the associations corresponding to neighboring regions will be similar, and increases efficiency in estimating these associations by facilitating the borrowing of information across neighboring regions. Model comparisons between the space-varying model (6) and the simpler model (5) are of interest, and can reveal, through the data, whether the group differences vary across brain regions. Prior distributions for the remaining parameters μ, Σ, σa 2,σb 2,σε 2,α,ν are chosen to be weakly informative, and the specific forms for these priors is discussed in Section 5 where the application is considered.

sec.title: 4.2 Bayesian computation and a missing data formulation
sec.p:
The model parameters are Θ = {β, a, b, μ, Σ, ,σa 2σb 2,σε 2,α,ν} and the posterior distribution takes the form PΘ(Θ|Y)∝ [Πi=1 46Πj=1 30Πk=1 mjPY(Yijk|μ,aij,bi,βj,σε 2,α,ν) ]× [Πi=1 46Πj=1 30Pa(aij|σa 2) ]× [Πi=1 46Pb(bi|σb 2) ]
×Pβ(β|Σ)Pμ(μ)PΣ(Σ)Pσa 2(σa 2)Pσb 2(σb 2)Pσε 2(σε 2)Pα(α)Pν(ν) where PY(Yijk|·) is the density of the Skew-t distribution (2); Pa(aij|·) and Pb(bi|·) are Gaussian densities corresponding to the random effect distributions; Pβ(β|Σ) corresponds to the multivariate conditional autoregressive prior; and the remaining densities correspond to standard prior distributions.

The posterior distribution can be computed using a Markov chain Monte Carlo sampler; however, the rather complex form of the Skew-t density function (2) makes the computational implementation of this sampler problematic as the resulting full conditional distributions take non-standard forms. While these non-standard full conditional distributions can be sampled using Metropolis–Hastings steps, we consider, as an alternative, a parameter expanded approach, based on the mixture representation (4). In particular, the mixture representation allows us to construct a Skew-t random variable Y ∼ St(μ, σ2, α, ν) using a three-stage hierarchical representation based on latent variables. At the first stage, Y|Z,W~N (μ+α/σZ1+α2,σ2W(1+α2) ), at the second stage Z|W ∼ TN(0, ∞)(0, W−1), where TN(0, ∞)(0, W−1) denotes a N(0, W−1) distribution truncated to the interval (0, ∞), and finally, W ∼ Gamma(ν/2, ν/2). That the resulting Y has the required Skew-t distribution follows directly from (4).

For each observation Yijk, we use the hierarchical representation, introducing (and conditioning on) latent variables Zijk|Wijkind~TN(0,∞)(0,Wijk -1), Wijkind~Gamma(ν/2,ν/2) and expand the parameter space from Θ to {Θ, Z, W}. with the resulting posterior taking form (7)PΘ,Z,W(Θ,Z,W|Y)∝LC(Y,Z,W;μ,aij,bi,βj,σε 2,α,ν)× [Πi=1 46Πj=1 30Pa(aij|σa 2) ]× [Πi=1 46Pb(bi|σb 2) ] ×Pβ(β|Σ)Pμ(μ)PΣ(Σ)Pσa 2(σa 2)Pσb 2(σb 2)Pσε 2(σε 2)Pα(α)Pν(ν) with the unknowns Z and W treated as missing data, and LC corresponding to a complete data likelihood with LC= [Πi=1 46Πj=1 30Πk=1 mjPY(Yijk|μ,aij,bi,βj,σε 2,α,Zijk,Wijk)PZ(Zijk|Wijk)PW(Wijk|ν) ]. We note that given Zijk and Wijk, the conditional density PY(Yijk|·, Zijk, Wijk) has a much simpler Gaussian form, and the complete data likelihood is then based on a product of standard distributions. Importantly, this representation facilitates the implementation of an MCMC sampling algorithm in standard software, and this sampler is programmed in the free software WinBUGS 1.4.18

sec.title: 5 Study of spectral slowing in down syndrome
sec.p:
Before applying our methodology to the DS MEG data, we explore the data to shed light on several features that motivate the proposed hierarchical modeling framework. The response data consist of measures obtained at 150 sensors, for each of n = 46 subjects (19 DS and 27 controls), resulting in a total of 150 × 46 = 6900 observations of mean frequency. For population level inference on the difference between DS and control subjects, it should be noted that the degree of replication is not the number of these measures (6900), but rather it is n = 46, corresponding to the number of subjects drawn from the two populations of interest. To avoid pseudoreplication, it is therefore important to apply the appropriate mixed model Yijk=μ+β1AGEi+β2GENDERi+β3DSi+bi+aij+εijk. We begin by fitting this mixed model under a standard Gaussian assumption bi|σb 2iid~N(0,σb 2), aij|σa 2iid~N(0,σa 2), εijk|σε 2iid~N(0,σε 2) based on three components of variability σa 2, σb 2, and σε 2. This initial model is fit using REML based on standard software for linear mixed models. The normal QQ-plot of the corresponding residuals is depicted in Figure 3. It is clear from the diagnostic plot that a Gaussian model for the errors is inadequate, with the residuals exhibiting both skewness and a significant degree of excess kurtosis. This lack of fit implies that the model inference, with respect to the group differences of interest, obtained from a Gaussian model will not be reliable. This then motivates the use of the Skew-t distribution, which can accommodate the positive asymmetry and heavy tail behavior observed in the residuals. Figure 3.
Exploratory analysis: normal QQ-plot of the residuals obtained from a Gaussian linear mixed model.

To investigate potential spatial variability in the associations of interest, we divide the dataset into 30 smaller datasets, each corresponding to one of the regions depicted in Figure 1. We then fit a standard mixed model, separately to each dataset, and obtain independent estimates of the region-specific regression coefficients. These raw estimates are presented in Figure 4, which illustrates the variability across the scalp regions through maps of the REML estimates, and through histograms depicting the distributions of these estimates. Spatial variability in the maps of raw estimates is evident, with neighboring regions having similar estimates. The maps illustrate how the associations vary spatially across scalp regions; however, we note that the corresponding estimates are obtained independently for each region. The approach of conducting a separate analysis for each region does not use the spatial correlation, which we can exploit to facilitate the borrowing of information across neighboring regions. As a result, the maps constructed in this manner can be unstable, with the most extreme values corresponding simply to those estimates having the highest variance.19,20 As an alternative, the space-varying regression (6), produces estimates through the fit of a single unified model, and the Markov random field prior results in a smoothing of estimates across the map. Figure 4.
Exploratory analysis of mean-frequency data. Left panel: Maps of the estimated coefficients obtained from 30 separate analyses for (a) age; (c) group; (e) gender. Right Panel: Histogram illustrating the distribution of exploratory estimates for (b) age; (d) group; (f) gender.

To address the complex features of these data more formally, we fit the proposed Skew-t space-varying mixed model, along with several submodels corresponding to different assumptions on the response distribution and regression structure. To examine the impact of distributional assumptions, space-varying regression models based on the skew-normal and Gaussian distributions are also fit. In addition, we fit a simpler model where the full space-varying regression is reduced, first to a model where only the coefficient of DS varies, and second, to a global model where all coefficients are assumed constant. In total, five models are considered for these data, and these models are summarized in Table 1. Table 1.

We fit the models based on weakly informative priors: μ ∼ N(0, 104); Σ ∼ Wishart(.02I, 3); σa ∼ Uniform(0, 100); σb ∼ Uniform(0, 100); σε ∼ Uniform(0, 100); α ∼ N(0, 10); ν ∼ Uniform(0.005, 30) with the priors for the other four models taking similar forms. Each model is fit by running two MCMC sampling chains in parallel for a total of 20,000 iterations, with the first 10,000 iterations of each chain discarded as burn-in. The remaining 10,000 samples of each chain are thinned with a spacing of 10 iterations to reduce memory requirements. In total, 2000 Monte Carlo samples are used for posterior inference.

We compare the models using the deviance information criterion (DIC), a generalization of Akaike's information criterion (AIC) for use with Bayesian hierarchical models.1 The DIC= D(Θ)¯+pD, where D(Θ) is the deviance (negative twice the log-likelihood), D(Θ)¯ is the posterior mean of the deviance, which measures the fit of the model, and pD is the effective number of parameters, which serves as a penalty for model complexity. The penalty term, pD, is defined by pD=D(Θ)¯-D(Θ¯) where Θ¯ is the posterior mean of Θ. Lower values of the DIC correspond to preferred models. Among a set of candidate models, Spiegelhalter et al.1 suggest that those models with DIC values not within a value of 7 of the best model (the model with the lowest DIC) have considerably less support. The minimum DIC estimates the model that will make the best short-term predictions, in the same spirit as the AIC.

The DIC values for each of the five models is presented in Table 1. Comparing across response distributions, there is a clear preference for the Skew-t distribution over the skew-normal and Gaussian. The ranking of the three distributions is inline with the exploratory diagnostics presented in Figure 3. The skew-normal accommodates the positive asymmetry observed in the residuals, and is therefore preferred over the Gaussian model; however, the Skew-t is able to accommodate both the skewness and the heavy tail behavior through the parameters α and ν respectively. The estimated posterior distributions, obtained from the model with lowest DIC, for these parameters is depicted in Figure 5. Comparing to the weakly informative priors assigned to these parameters, the posterior densities are considerably more concentrated, indicating a strong degree of Bayesian learning through prior-to-posterior movement. The equal-tail 95% posterior credible intervals are (0.322, 0.589) for α and (1.230, 1.385) for ν. Interestingly, the posterior distribution for ν indicates very heavy, almost Cauchy-like, tails for the regression errors. Such heavy tails may arise when an important factor is excluded from a regression model. While we have accounted for Down syndrome, age, gender, and scalp region, the extreme values generating the heavy tails may relate to an important, yet unknown factor not considered in the present study. Along the lines of Bayesian outlier detection, it may be possible to examine the posterior of Wijk, the latent variable used to generate the heavy tail behavior, to identify the specific subjects, regions, or sensors, that contribute to these extreme residuals. Examining these further may then lend clues as to the existence of a missing factor, and this is an interesting avenue for future work. Figure 5.
Estimated posterior density (solid curve) and prior density (dashed curve) for (a) α and (b) ν.

Of the three Skew-t models fit to the data, Table 1 indicates that the models allowing the coefficient of DS to vary spatially are preferred over the global model that assumes the difference between groups is fixed across regions. The data thus support a model where the difference between the DS and control populations is differential across brain regions, with some regions differing in mean frequency more than others. For the two Skew-t models that allow for a spatially varying difference between groups, the DIC suggests that adjusting for age and gender through spatially varying coefficients yields superior performance when compared with a global adjustment.

Examining results from the optimal model further, Figure 6 summarizes the posterior distribution of the space-varying coefficients through maps of the posterior mean estimates, and through boxplots of the Monte Carlo posterior samples, which summarize the posterior distribution of each coefficient in relation to the null value of β = 0 indicated with the horizontal line in each of panels (b), (d) and (f). Each boxplot depicted in these panels summarizes the posterior distribution of a single regression coefficient associated with a particular patch on the scalp, leading to a total of 30 boxplots summarizing the space-varying association structure across the scalp. Figure 6.
Posterior summaries of the space-varying coefficients from the Skew-t model with lowest DIC. Left panel: posterior mean map for (a) age; (c) DS; (e) gender. Right panel: Boxplots (arranged in increasing order by posterior median) illustrating the posterior distributions of the spatially varying coefficients for (b) age; (d) DS; (f) gender. The six temporal regions are specifically marked in panel (c). DIC: deviance information criterion; DS: Down syndrome.

Comparison of the maps in Figure 6, to those of Figure 4, reveals the impact of the Markov random field prior in stabilizing the estimates through spatial smoothing. Of primary interest in the current study are estimates associated with DS, shown in Figure 6, panels (c) and (d). Comparing the boxplots with the horizontal line at β = 0 (corresponding to no difference between groups) indicates that, in general, individuals with DS tend to have lower values of (log) mean frequency; however, the most striking differences are observed in the six temporal regions. The 6 temporal regions are a subset of the original 30 scalp regions corresponding to the temporal lobes, and these regions are specifically marked in Figure 6, panel (c). The 95% credible intervals for the coefficient of DS associated with the temporal regions are presented in Table 2. These 95% intervals all exclude the null value of β = 0, and have upper bounds well below this value. The population-average mean frequency for DS patients is significantly lower compared to healthy controls in the six temporal regions. For example, at the region labeled ‘Right Temporal A’, the population-average log-mean frequency for DS patients is lower than that of control patients, with a 95% CI for this difference being (−0.317, −0.193). Similarly this interval is estimated as (−0.322, −0.194) at ‘Left Temporal A’, a similar region corresponding to the opposite brain hemisphere. Table 2.

sec.title: 6 Discussion
sec.p: We have developed a novel statistical modeling framework for the spectral analysis of resting state brain activity, and have illustrated our approach with application to an MEG-based observational study, comparing the resting state brain rhythms of individuals with DS to those of controls. Our analysis reveals spectral slowing in the brain activity of DS subjects, particularly in the temporal regions associated with both sides of the brain, and we have estimated a spatially smoothed map illustrating the scalp topography of the group differences. The proposed statistical methodology brings together several strands of research, including previous work on skew-elliptical distributions6 as well as work on regression models with spatially varying coefficients based on multivariate conditional autoregressive priors.14 Future work will involve an extension of the model to accommodate multivariate spectral features, for example, an analysis of the bivariate response representing the center of mass of the frequency autocorrelation is also of interest, and may help to further characterize how the spectral signature of MEG readings differs between the DS and control populations.
